properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Lake effect snow squalls expected Wednesday. Lake effect flurries and local snow squalls are expected to develop Wednesday midday and persist through Thursday morning. Local snowfall accumulations of 15 to 25 cm will be possible overnight with an additional 5 centimetres possible Thursday before the squalls move out of the area. Snow squall warnings will likely be required. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-13T12:13:01-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-12T20:14:01-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3495043188.2019
Area: Greater Sudbury and vicinity, West Nipissing - French River, Espanola - Killarney, Manitoulin Island
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Lake effect snow squalls expected Wednesday. Southerly winds over the relatively warm waters of Lake Superior are expected to produce flurries and local snow squalls on Wednesday. The squalls could start as early as Wednesday morning and are expected to continue through Wednesday night. Local snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 cm are possible on Wednesday, however areas closer to Lake Superior could see locally higher amounts of 15 to 25 cm. Additional amounts of 5 to 15 cm are possible Wednesday night into Thursday morning. Local blowing snow reducing visibilities will also be a concern. Local snow squalls are forecast to taper off when the winds shift to the northwest on Thursday. ### Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-13T08:04:12-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-12T16:05:12-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2010809417.2019
Area: White River - Dubreuilville, Wawa - Pukaskwa Park, Agawa - Lake Superior Park
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter weather travel advisory in effect for tonight. Lake effect snow bands may affect areas well inland from Lake Huron tonight with 2 to 5 cm possible. Travel may be impacted due to accumulating snow and low visibility in heavy snow. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A total of 15 to 25 centimetres of snow is expected by this evening or tonight. The snow will be accompanied by strong winds which will reduce visibilities in blowing snow. The snow will change to freezing rain or rain this evening over the Lower North Shore. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-13T08:57:29-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain is forecast to continue over the Islands into Wednesday morning, with total rainfall accumulations of 20 to 30 millimetres expected. Rain will change to flurries on Wednesday morning as brisk westerly winds usher in colder temperatures. A snow squall watch has been issued for Wednesday afternoon and evening. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain will continue across Nova Scotia this evening, then change to to flurries late tonight or Wednesday morning as cold westerly winds move into the region and temperatures quickly fall below freezing. Driving conditions may become difficult as the cold air and flurries push eastward across the province. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant rainfall is expected. Total rainfall: 50 to 80 mm. Locations: southwestern Newfoundland from Channel-Port aux Basques to Grey River. Time span: continuing until late Wednesday morning. Remarks: Further rainfall amounts of 30 to 40 mm are expected tonight before the rain tapers off Wednesday morning. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Lake effect snow squalls today through Wednesday morning. Flurries and local snow squalls continue and are expected to persist into Wednesday morning. Local snowfall amounts of 5 to 15 cm are possible today and amounts of near 15 cm are possible tonight into Wednesday morning. Local blowing snow reducing visibilities to near zero will also be a concern. Local snow squalls are forecast to taper off when the winds shift to southwest Wednesday afternoon. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall amounts: 5 to 15 cm, highest amounts inland. Locations: Cartwright and south to L'Anse-au-Clair. Time span: Continuing through to Wednesday morning. Remarks: Snow, at times heavy, along the Labrador Straits will spread northward, reaching Cartwright this evening. The snow will then transition to rain from south to north overnight into Wednesday morning with a period of freezing rain likely over inland areas. Highest snowfall accumulations are expected inland and over higher terrain, particularly along the Trans-Labrador Highway, where temperatures will be slower to rise. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-13T11:44:04-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-12T19:45:04-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0590981426.2019

properties.Title: Storm Surge Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Higher than normal water levels with large waves are expected near the coast. Warning of potential breaking sea conditions and overwash issued jointly by Fisheries and Oceans Canada (Science) and the Meteorological Service of Canada - Quebec Area on 2019-11-12. An intense low pressure system will generate strong northeasterly winds over the areas specified below. The combination of these winds and the fact that we are currently in a period of mid-sized tidal range could produce minor breaking sea conditions along the coast near theses localities on Tuesday and at the times specified (Eastern Standard Time). Rimouski - Mont-Joli: 2019-11-12, from 12 PM to 4 PM. Matane: 2019-11-12, from 12 PM to 4 PM. Forillon Park - Gaspé - Percé: 2019-11-12, from 11:30 AM to 3:30 PM. Baie-Comeau: 2019-11-12, from 11:30 AM to 3:30 PM. Sept-Îles - Port-Cartier: 2019-11-12, from 11:30 AM to 0:30 PM. ### Coastal erosion is possible in vulnerable areas. Storm surge warnings are issued when water levels pose a threat to coastal regions. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-12T23:59:28-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-12T16:43:28-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2757789992.2019
Area: Mont-Joli area, Le Bic - Rimouski area, Matane, Forillon National Park - Gaspé area, Percé area, Baie-Comeau, Baie-Trinité area, Sept-Îles - Port-Cartier area
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Total snowfall: 20 to 40 cm. Locations: Hopedale and vicinity, Postville - Makkovik. Time span: overnight tonight until Thursday morning. Remarks: The snow will be accompanied by strong north to northeasterly winds gusting up to 80 km/h on Wednesday giving reduced visibilities in blowing snow. Winds will further increase from the north to northwest Wednesday night, with local gusts of 110 km/h expected, causing blizzard like conditions. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-13T11:44:17-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-12T19:45:17-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2762866522.2019

Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 20 to 30 cm is expected. Locations: Rigolet, Upper Lake Melville, Eagle River. Time span: Tonight and Wednesday. Remarks: The heaviest snowfall is expected overnight and Wednesday morning. Snow will be accompanied with north to northeasterly winds gusting to 50 or 60 km/h, resulting in blowing snow over exposed areas. Over eastern areas of the Trans-Labrador Highway in the Eagle River forecast region, a period of freezing rain is expected Wednesday morning. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-13T11:44:52-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-12T19:45:52-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1256342380.2019

properties.Title: Wreckhouse Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds are expected or occurring. Maximum wind gusts: 100 to 120 km/h. Time span: continuing until early Wednesday morning. Remarks: Strong southeasterly winds with gusts up to 120 km/h are expected to continue tonight before diminishing early Wednesday morning when they shift to southwesterly. ### Wreckhouse wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. Rain will continue across Nova Scotia tonight, then change to flurries overnight or Wednesday morning as cold westerly winds move into the region and temperatures quickly fall below freezing. Total rainfall accumulations are expected to be quite variable, with forecast amounts ranging from 30 to 65 mm and locally higher amounts possible along parts of the Atlantic coast. Driving conditions may become difficult overnight or Wednesday morning as the cold air and flurries push eastward across the province. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-13T11:59:14-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-12T20:01:14-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4206341425.2019

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain is expected or occurring. Freezing rain or rain will change to periods of rain this afternoon. The travelling public are urged to prepare for potentially difficult driving conditions in areas of freezing rain. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. Rain is forecast to continue until early Wednesday morning, with total forecast rainfall accumulations ranging from 40 to 60 millimetres over the region. Rain is expected to change to flurries early on Wednesday morning as cold westerly winds move across the province. Flurries will persist through the day on Wednesday and into Wednesday night, when conditions will become favourable for the development of snow squalls. A snow squall watch has been issued for Wednesday night. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Ice build-up due to freezing rain is expected or occurring. Light northerly outflow winds continue to bring modified arctic air through mainland valleys as a Pacific frontal system crosses the region. The combination of warm air from the system overriding the cold outflow is producing freezing rain, or freezing drizzle in valleys throughout the Terrace region. Freezing precipitation will persist until this afternoon when temperatures finally rise above zero. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots will become icy, slippery and hazardous. Ice build-up may cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-13T02:29:04-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-12T18:41:04-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0588506983.2019
Area: North Coast - inland including Terrace
